awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Medium-Band K-band Survey with Gemini to Identify the First Quenching Galaxies and Extreme Episodes of Galaxy Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
In the early universe, massive galaxies grew rapidly through intense bursts of star formation, and then quenched (abruptly stopped forming stars at high rates).  Principal Investigators Papovich and Marchesini will use the Second Florida Multi-Object Imaging Near-Infrared Grism Observational Spectrometer (FLAMINGOS2, F2) on the Gemini-South Telescope to conduct a census of these distant massive galaxies and study the underlying physical processes that transform the galaxies from star forming to quenched. The team will participate in Warrior-Scholar boot camps at Texas A&M University, which assist students as they transition from active military service to higher education. In addition, the team will mentor a summer student selected from the Tufts University Visiting and Early Research Scholars Experience Program. This program has a partnership with Historically Black Colleges.

The team are using their custom built near infrared blue filter (centered at 2.0 micron) and red filter (centered at 2.3 micron) in order to be sensitive to the 4000 Angstrom/Balmer break for galaxies at redshifts 3 < z < 6. The team will conduct the 0.5 square degree F2 Extragalactic Near-IR K-Split Survey (FENIKS). The survey will image three deep legacy fields, the Cosmic Evolution Survey, the Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey – South, and the Ultra Deep Survey. The team will study the stellar populations and supermassive black holes in massive (log(M/Msun) > 10.9) galaxies and determine when galaxies first begin to quench. The team will also identify and study hundreds of extreme galaxies with intense nebular emission, which are important in the context of galaxy formation and cosmic reionization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Marchesini and his team at Tufts Universities, in collaboration with Dr. Papovich and his team at Texas A&M, used novel near-IR data to conduct detailed studies of the formation and evolution of distant massive galaxies. The team upgraded the F2 near-IR camera at the Gemini Observatory using two novel filters that split the K-band, designed to be sensitive to the Balmer break for galaxies in the first 2 billion years of cosmic history). The PIs Marchesini and Papovich led an approved Gemini Large, Long-term Program (LLP) to image 0.5 square degrees with these filters, the F2 two-K-band redshift survey (formerly ZF2K; renamed FENIKS).

The Tufts University based team (Dr. Marchesini and PhD student Kumail Zaidi) led the construction of multi-wavelength photometric catalog in the FENIKS UDS field, and the catalogs of photometric redshifts, rest-frame colors and magnitudes, and stellar population properties derived with both FAST and DenseBasis. The constructed catalogs were released to the public and the astronomy community.

Tufts University PhD student Kumail Zaidi used the FENIKS catalogs in UDS and the COSMOS fields to perform a detailed analysis of the relationship between the stellar mass and the dark matter halo mass over the past 12.3 billion years (i.e., since z=5; representing ~90% of cosmic history). The stellar mass - halo mass relation was constrained using measurements of the galaxy clustering and abundances, and introducing a novel Bayesian halo occupation distribution modeling approach. This analysis showed that the star formation is tightly coupled to the halo mass, and we observed “downsizing” in the stellar mass buildup within halos, where the most massive halos and galaxies formed their stars earlier, followed by progressively smaller systems.

The stellar population properties and environments of distant (z~3-5) ultra-massive galaxies were investigated using spectroscopic data from Keck-MOSFIRE.

The program contributed to the training and PhD thesis of Tufts University PhD student Kumail Zaidi. Through the Tufts University Visiting and Early Research Scholars Experience (VERSE) initiative, the awarded NSF program contributed to the education of four under-represented STEM undergraduate students, providing them with opportunities to do research in astrophysics during the summers and the academic years and, through it, learning and strengthening their coding skills and performing data science.
